captions.text:
My name is Christian
von Koenigsegg.

I'm 40 years old and for half
of my life I've been on the

quest to be a leader in the
hyper car industry utilizing

Swedish design combined with
visionary technical solutions.

Our latest car, the Agera R, is
built in the old hangars of

a former Swedish fighter
jet squadron.

Their symbol, a ghost, is now
proudly painted on the back of
every Koenigsegg.
[CAR  ENGINE REVVING]
[CAR  ENGINE REVVING]

Carbon fiber is really one of
the fundamentals really to

make a car strong, very light,
safe, and have fantastic
performance.

It creates massive rigidity but
does not add weight which

is crucial if you want to make
a really efficient, fast, and
fun sports car to drive.

As far as we're aware, our cars
are the most carbon fiber

intense cars in production right
now, as we have over 400
different carbon fiber pieces.

This here is an intake
for the engine--
intake plenum.

We have some pressurized turbo
pipes, valve cover, and even

parts like the engine, as we
can see here, are made of

carbon fiber, especially the
parts up top on the engine to
get the center of gravity low.

So what we're seeing here
is something as
very simple as a tube.
It's a turbo piping.

And what I have in front
of me here is a
machined mold from aluminium.

Even a simple detail like a tube
needs a lot of thought to
make it perfect.

The CAD model is flowed to
check that the flow is

perfect, that it has enough
volume to pass enough air to

the engine at top power levels
and top RPM levels.

It also has to have a shape
which is strong enough and to

calculate the thickness of the
carbon fiber so that it can
take the boost pressure.

You can see here that it's kind
of a funky shape to it.

That its flow is optimized
for this curve.

We have an integrated mount
here for a pressure and
temperature sensor.

Actually, when we manufacturer
a carbon fiber part from this

tool, the first thing we do is
to put a release agent here.

Because in the carbon fiber
pre-preg, which I have here,

which is actually the material
the part is made out of, it's

pre-impregnated with two
component epoxy.

So if this would be put down
here without releasing, it we

would actually stick
to the tube.

And then this material, the
carbon fiber, is cut to suit
the tube part.

This is not optimized
for this.
I just took a small piece.

But it's applied like this and
layer by layer, different

amount of layers depending
on the need.

So that's actually what's going
to become the part.
Then we need to pressurize.

We need heat and pressure to
consolidate this to get it to

have the right strength and
the right properties.

So in order for the rest of the
processing material not to

get stuck into the carbon fiber
and the epoxy, we put

this kind of a release film here
which is easy to tear off
of the part when it's done.

And it also makes sure that this
breathing fabric, as it's

called-- it's called
a breather--

doesn't stick to the
carbon fiber piece.

And what this does is make sure
that the pressure that

this is subjected to, or the
vacuum that we also suck out,

that it gets spread out
and that we don't
get pockets of air.

It's making sure the atmospheric
differences are
controlled over the surface.

So at the end, we put this
bagging material over the

whole part and then we seal it
off with kind of a goo that is

similar to black chewing
gum, I would say.

So, basically, these are the
elements included in the
production of the part.

And it's quite intricate,
especially with a tube like

this that has to then-- we put
carbon fiber here, we put
carbon fiber here.
And then these--
I'll take this off right now--

then they have to
match together.

And I'll need this bagging
material to come in to the

tube to pressurize the tube from
the inside and then to

seal off the tube from
the outside.

Of course, the thinner,
the lighter but
also less strong part.

So if it's a safety critical
part or, like this, a

pressurized part, it really
needs to be calculated well to

have the right amount
of carbon fiber.

You never want to put more
carbon fiber than you need

into a part because,
first of all,
carbon fiber is expensive.

So the part becomes
unnecessarily expensive.

It takes more time to apply
the carbon fiber than is
actually needed.

And in the end also the part
becomes heavier, which is

maybe the worst part in a
super light sports car.
The end result is this tube.

So in the end, it's a quite
simple looking part, but

there's a lot of thought that
has gone into what it becomes
in the end.

Already, of course, from shaping
the part, but also

when it comes to laying it
up and getting the right
consolidation.

You can see straight from the
tool, you get a quite nice

even surface that doesn't
require a lot of the hand
fettling afterwards.

As it is a very complex
technology, there are many

types of weaves, many types of
carbon fiber strand, and

different philosophies
of how to apply them.

It's a little bit of a black art
really, and really lessons

learned and what kind
of philosophies
you're working towards.

But we have been developing
carbon fiber parts since 1994.

So I would say we have quite
good experience and can create

extreme, lightweight, and strong
parts based on the

knowledge we have and the
analysis tools we have.

So it's really a labor-intensive
process and

the persons involved in the
manufacturing really needs to

know what they're doing to
get the desired result.

Of course, here, we have a
much more complex part.

So you can imagine what has to
go into this compared to a
simple tube.

And what's nice about carbon
fiber is you can vary the

strength and thicknesses in
different areas with no limit.

It's just how much thought you
want to put into it and how

much labor you want
to put into it.

But it can be so optimized, like
this corner can have a
little bit of extra carbon.
It can be thinner here.

We can have a different
direction.

Not many other materials gives
that kind of freedom.

At the same time, not many other
materials can soak up so

much time in the production
process.

But that's what makes the
car extreme and what
it is in the end.

Koenigsegg and carbon fiber are
very closely integrated

and it has to be that way
in this very competitive
market we're in.

comments.text: Holy shit I never knew that's what goes into making one of those ﻿
comments.author: Demz

comments.text:
This has been my favorite car company for years. This car, is not only 
brilliant, the engineering, manufacturing process, the passion, is just 
absolutely amazing. 
Ferrari and Lambo, along with Pagani (which isn't really in the same class) 
are brilliant designers, fabricators and engineering companies, but 
Koenigsegg is just not only a remarkable company, but their cars are 
absolutely wonderful.. wonderful doesn't describe them.. more like Amazing, 
or Astounding. 
As an engineer, business owner and carbon fiber parts manufacturer, I can 
not only appreciate the amount of work that goes into one of these cars, 
this video just simply leaves my jaw dropped at the attention to detail and 
incredible engineering work that went into this car. Koenigsegg is my 
favorite car.. hopefully one of these days before I'm either dead, or too 
old to enjoy it, I can buy one. I work my ass off, keeping myself, my 
family and my employees fed and in homes, that's my primary concern. My 
goal, is to one day, ride in my own Koenigsegg. My absolute dream car. I 
started another company, working on patents and designs, and my goal is to 
make the company thrive and take the profits from it and hopefully buy one 
of these some day soon. Until then, I can simply just dream.﻿

comments.author: M3Conv

comments.text:
+M3Conv Agree 100% as well. Been called a Koenigsegg hater before and that 
certainly isn't true. You basically summed it up. 

Oh right, didn't know that. Can't imagine anything road legal is hitting a 
6:30 any time soon.
comments.author: Jamie Withers

comments.text:
+JFPW3097
I agree 100%.

Some people call me a hater on Koenigsegg yet nothing could be further than 
the truth. For the resources they have (only 18 people work there) they 
build amazing machines like this one.

But when people start to say they have access to higher technology or will 
smash anything McLaren, Ferrari or Porsche can build round a track i have 
to comment :)

btw I think that the 6.30 came from some lap time app that CvK was 
demonstrating on a video, i am pretty sure that he was not trying to say 
that it was an actual time, but that won't stop some people claiming it 
must be true!
comments.author: M3Conv

comments.text:
+M3Conv Didn't know that! Haha, that's quite funny. Last i read about their 
financial state was that in 2012 (i think) they were borrowing huge amounts 
and were close to going bankrupt. So i suspect Koenigsegg are in some 
serious debt.
I never caught onto the Koenigsegg hype, which really has spiked with the 
announcement of the One:1 and that video of the Agera R vs. Veyron Vitesse.

No doubt i think they make great cars, in terms of build quality and 
performance, but in my opinion none of their cars are comparable with the 
P1, 918 or LaFerrari. The technology in each of those three cars, far 
exceeds the technology in the One:1, or any of the Agera range. 

I just don't see why people are comparing the One:1 to the P1, 918 or 
LaFerrari when those three each produce about 400bhp less than the One:1 
and are produced in far higher qualities. Even still, around a track, 
namely the Nurburgring, i don't think the Agera R or One:1 will run as good 
a time as everyone thinks. Too much power, most of which isn't usable 
around most of the course, and that was shown when the test driver even 
crashed the car doing a lap.

I was going to say they won't beat the 918 time, but that is irrelevant. 
From what i am told the 918's time wasn't the fastest, and the car is still 
being tweaked and updated and will continue to do so. 
McLaren have already said the P1 will be getting updated as battery 
technology advances. Not to mention the time the P1 posted was already very 
quick. So whatever time the One:1 posts is largely irrelevant, not to 
mention i am not fully convinced it will post a quicker time. Even so, 
certainly not as quick as the 6:30 claims Koenigsegg are making.
comments.author: Jamie Withers

comments.text:
+JFPW3097 One thing all reviewers say about the 458 Speciale is that it 
feels incredibly nimble, light and precise so i would not be surprised if 
it was not one of the lightest full sports cars out there (although i know 
where you are coming from with Ferrari being known to bend the truth).

However as an Engineer myself i know that development and manufacturing at 
this level is phenomenally expensive. So when people belive Koenigsegg are 
as  high tech a company  or can do things that Porsche  or Ferrari are not 
capable of, it always amuses me.

A good example is Koenigsegg turn over around 10Million euros a year, 
Porsche spent 20Million just developing the steering wheel for the 918! (i 
am being serious here).

Personally i cannot understand how they keep the factory going with just a 
few million Euros coming in a year, so to bring out an all new model would 
be all but impossible.
comments.author: M3Conv

comments.text:
+M3Conv Yeah, i side tracked just a tad, but yes too much speculation to 
say. I know the P1 weights are bang on, LaFerrari not so much.
Koenigsegg seem to be honest, can't tell though. Watch Ferrari though 
pretty sure a 458 Speciale weighs around 1400kg by Ferrari's claims, 
wouldn't surprise me if it was more in the region of 1450-1500kg.

Either way although the One:1 is full CF construction, the car is pretty 
bulky design wise. Dimensions, the car is small for a hypercar, or at least 
one of the smaller ones. The engine is pretty beefy, 5.0L Twin Turbo V8 
pushing out 1340bhp, or 1360hp.
I was going to say the engine probably takes a majority of that weight, but 
their website claims the engine weighs 197kg which seems very light to me 
considering the power output. The chassis only weighs 72kg as well, so not 
really sure if i am honest. Transmission perhaps? The Koenigsegg 
transmission doesn't seem as smooth or quick as most i have seen, e.g. 
Porsche's PDK, Ferrari's Dual-Clutch or McLaren's.

What i am trying to get my head around is that the Agera R's EU Kerb weight 
is only 1435kg... Personally i would like to see Koenigsegg start fresh 
instead of reiterating the same design for the last 20 years odd. If they 
did i think they would come up with a much more interesting design which 
would probably perform better aerodynamically and be less bulky, thus 
saving weight. Who knows though.
comments.author: Jamie Withers

comments.text:
+JFPW3097
Good maths! but too much speculation to be any real use unfortunately, and 
more importantly we are going off point.

My point was for 'the most expensive car in the world' constructed of 
almost all of carbon fibre does not appear to be ground breakingly light if 
it weighs 1360kg (assuming that Koenigsegg are not lying also :)

Its about the same as a US spec 458 Speciale or a 997 GT3RS which are much 
humbler cars made of much humbler materials :)
comments.author: M3Conv

comments.text:
+M3Conv My sources are customers who i have spoken to and weighed their 
cars. The only accurate results you will get is from customers as Ferrari 
constantly lie about the performance figures of their cars. 

Anyway, the LaFerrari owners manual states the cars weight is 1490kg. Not 
sure if that is dry or kerb, but if that is the dry weight then the result 
lines up well with what i calculated and what the owner recorded.

The LaFerrari is a bigger car than the P1. It has a 6.3L N/A V12, compared 
to a 3.8L TT V8. Even with the turbo's, the engine is likely to weigh more. 
Yes, the P1's battery is bigger, but the LaFerrari fuel tank is bigger and 
hold about 20kg more fuel. P1 = 16.3 gals US, LaFerrari = 22.8 gals US. 
Multiply both by 6.2lbs which is rough weight of a US gal of gasoline and 
there is about a 20kg difference if you convert from lbs to kg.

Put it this way, that customer LaFerrari was weighed at 1675kg, that 
includes a driver and i assume full fluids and tank. The P1 weighed the 
same is 1615kg. Subtract the driver from both and we have 1600kg and 
1540kg. Now subtract the weight of fuel in both cars, P1 = 1495kg, 
LaFerrari = 1535kg. Weight difference of 40kg would seem closer, no?

Now lets convert that back to EU Kerb weight, which is half a tank of fuel. 
P1 fuel tank = 45.8kg, LaFerrari = 63.5kg half both weights and add results 
to each respective car. Approximate EU Kerb weight for both cars:

P1 ~ 1520kg, LaFerrari ~ 1570kg, equals an approximate 50kg difference in 
weight. Bare in mind yes, while heavier than a 458 Italia, the LaFerrari 
uses a bigger engine and a hybrid power train. I also it is heavier by 
100kg, guarantee if you weighed a 458 it is much heavier than any claims.

Quite enjoying this, wish to continue? ;)
comments.author: Jamie Withers

comments.text:
That does not sound right at all, i would check your sources.

I would find it difficult to believe that the P1 is lighter than the 
LaFerrari as for start it has a much smaller and lighter hybrid battery 
pack and only 1 electric motor.

The LaFerrari is normally aspirated so no extra weight from turbos, inter 
coolers, plumbing etc.

Your weight puts it 100kg heavier than a regular non carbon 458!
comments.author: M3Conv

comments.text:
+M3Conv Because Ferrari lied about the true weight of the car. EU Kerb 
weight is the weight of the car with 50% fuel, 100% fluids. The One:1's EU 
Kerb weight is 1360kg. The McLaren P1's EU Kerb weight is around 1520kg.

The LaFerrari was weighed at 1675kg with a driver, but apparently not 
completely topped with fluids. Not sure how much fuel, but assuming the 
driver was 75kg, then the LaFerrari is around the 1600kg mark with what i 
assume is full tank and fluids. So, given LaFerrari fuel tank is a claimed 
86 litres or 22.8 gals US, and 1 gal of gasoline is 6.2lbs, we have: Fuel 
load = 141.4lbs = 64kg.

The LaFerrari's EU Kerb weight is going to be around 1570kg, which is 
significantly higher than claimed weight originally and is 50kg heavier 
than the P1, if all assumed is correct. I have assumed that the LaFerrari 
was the heaviest it could be with that 1675kg weight, full tank, full 
fluids and a driver, so if that isn't the case then it is actually heavier 
than i calculated. 

By the way the weights for the LaFerrari and McLaren P1 are weights 
recorded by customers, not by the manufacturers. I can link where i got the 
information from if you want any clarification.
comments.author: Jamie Withers

comments.text:
You could be correct, they may be both the same kerb weight at around 
1340kg.
comments.author: M3Conv

comments.text:

comments.text:
+swtnlnly The box (curing oven) is not for curing or a catalyst inducer. 
their are achieving a process called Sintering. Which is the increase of 
the molecular properties through diffusion of atomic orbitals. Not many 
companies do this cause of time and money.

negative pressure. (Source: I worked on the Starship 1 program at 
Beechcraft)

comments.text:
+Danel Leunda You calculate the strength of the material and how the energy

comments.author: Völundr Frey

comments.text:
+Völundr Frey How can you decide or simulate how many layers and in which 
direction you need to put it into a mold?
comments.author: Danel Leunda

comments.text:
You design a mold in the computer, that improves the aerodynamics 
properties of your car. You get a CNC-machine and router it out of a block 
of aluminium. Then you use your calculations from the design process to 
decide how many layers, and in which direction the carbon fibre should be. 
Then you put on the film, and breathing cloth. Pop it in a bag, and bake it 
in an oven. 

Or you buy some cheap plastic shit from china and roll of carbon fibre 
tape.

comments.text: I dont understand the part where the ghost logo at the back. Explain to me.﻿
comments.author: Sub Zero

comments.text:
The ghost symbol was the symbol of a swedish flight squadron. However, this 
squadron went bust many years ago. As this was happening, Koenigsegg was 
looking for a new place to produce their cars due to a fire destroying 
their old factory.

Koenigsegg was then contacted by one of the pilots, offering their old 
hangar because the squadron didn't want to lose it to someone thet didn't 
know, the state etc.
However, they would only give the hangar to Koenigsegg on one condition: 
That they would continue the "spirit" of the squadron so that it wouldn't 
die out.

After that, every Koenigsegg got the squadron ghost logo painted as a 
standard.
comments.author: The Scandinavian Gaming Channel

comments.text:
No it does not. "Agera" simply is the verb to act in Swedish. The company's 
factory used to be a hanger of a Swedish fighter jet company. The Logo of 
the fighter jet company is a Ghost. So to honour them they put the Logo on 
their cars.

comments.author: Dan Maltby

comments.text:
Have to agree with Patrik Manni as it's true! Nearly 20 years as a 
composite technician myself working on F1 cars, Touring Cars, LM cars,GP 
bikes and many other subjects concerning carbon fibre and that's how it's 
spelt, not fiber! The pre-preg used by all good quality sports cars 
manufactures will be top grade to very high standards and they aren't cheap 
at all! I personally have used some pre-pregs costing up to £1000 per 
linear metre though it's fairly rare these days as manufacturing of carbon 
has become a bit cheaper! ﻿
